text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The electoral commission announces voter registration for general elections this year will start on May 19 and end on June 22.
- Cabinet minister Nicholas Biwott declares himself a clean man over the murder of the 1990 murder of former foreign affairs minister Robert Ouko.
- Police kill two suspected robbers outside a Nairobi temple.
- Calm returns to Marakwet and Pokot districts after local leaders reach a peace agreement to end cattle rustling in the area.
- Armed gangsters raid a business firm at Nairobi's Jomo Kenyatta International Airport and steal property worth at least 1.2 million shillings.
- Pressure from top government officials may force the Nairobi City Council to raise water bills by 40 percent to pay off a foreign firm.
- The hijackers of a Kenyan fishing trawler have removed all the 36 crew members from the ship and taken them to an unknown destination in Somaliland.
- Ousted chairman of the opposition Kenya National Congress Chibule wa Tsuma is expelled from the party by its national executive council.
- Eleven people drown while three others are reported missing following heavy rains in the country over the last few days.
